pictographic: tattoo, which is one of the earliest forms of writing. Writing was the basis of much Ancient Chinese culture, so 文 was later generalized to also mean "cultured."

丷 on top is 人 (person) written upside down. 口 means mouth. 儿 at the bottom was originally written as 八, which means separation or opening. 兑 shows a person opening his mouth wide and laughing hard --- 兑 means happiness. phonetic: 兑 provides the sound ''uì"

pictographic: the Black Tortoise. 

In ancient Chinese mythology, the Black Tortoise is the guardian of the North (the rest of the Four Guardians are: the White Tiger of the West, the Azure Dragon of the East, and the Vermilion bird of the South).

phonetic only
You (你) whom I directly address are a person (亻) who is near (尔) me.
In Ancient Chinese values, a good (好) life for a man is to have a wife (女)  and children (子).
In an invitation or request (请), pretty (青) words are spoken (讠). 青 (qīng) also hints at the pronunciation of 请 (qǐng).

问 depicts a person standing by a door (门) and speaking (口) with the people inside, sometimes to greet them, other times to ask them questions. 

门 (mén) also suggests pronunciation of 问 (wèn).

fields.definition_3: honorific (to show respect to the person/group being addressed)
fields.mnemonic_explanation:
People used to bury their cowrie shells (贝) underground (土) to guard against stealing because shells, as the currency in Ancient China, were very valuable (贵). 

(Note that the upper part of 贵 is not exactly 土, but a unique variation of it.)
女 as a character has the same meaning as it does as a radical.
As there are no useful mnemonic explanations, we suggest you focus on practicing the stroke order to help you remember this character.
Radical 口 indicates 呢 is related to speech. Radical 尼 (ní) hints at the pronunciation of 呢 (ne).
小 as a character has the same meaning as it does as a radical.
Radical 女 indicates that an elder sister is a woman. 且 (qiě) suggests the pronunciation of 姐 (jiě).
fields.example_1_meaning: what one calls an elder sister

fields.mnemonic_explanation: When you are tied up with a rope (丩), you use your mouth (口) to call (叫) for help.

Radical 亻suggests that 什 is related to people because only humans (亻) ask the question "what?" 

十 (shí) hints at the pronouciation of 什 (shén).

Due to the extreme abstraction of this character as it evolved, its historic explanation isn't very helpful for remembering it. You can still use your imagination to create your own memory aid though! :)
When it is getting dark at dusk (夕), you cannot see people's faces clearly, so you have to call out (口) someone's name (名) to make sure you got the right person.
In ancient matrilineal societies, children inherited the surnames (姓) of their mothers (女), who gave them life (生).

A herd of cows (牛) are walking before (先) the cowboy (儿). 

(Note that the upper part of 先 is not exactly 牛, but a unique variation of it where the vertical stroke does not go through at the bottom.)
fields.example_1_meaning: Mister (someone who's born before you should be addressed with respect)

fields.mnemonic_explanation: 生 as a character has the same meaning as it does as a radical.
Plums (李) are the "children" (子) of plum trees (木).
Friends walk together hand (𠂇) in hand (又).
Two friends (朋) have dinner together, each enjoying a serving of short ribs (⺝).
In Ancient China, kings (王 as a character) have seals made of jade (王 as a radical) that symbolize their power.

2nd definition: Something that can be done in broad daylight (日) is a right (正) thing to do, and it should be affirmed (是). Note that the lower part of 是 is not exactly 正, but a unique variation of it. 

As for the 1st definition, due to the extreme abstraction of this character as it evolved, its historic explanation isn't very helpful for remembering it. You can still use your imagination to create your own memory aid though! :)
老 originally meant an aged (耂) person (匕). With age comes experience (2nd definition). Later, 老 become a description for everything old (1st definition).
In Ancient China, the turban (巾) of a sword ( ﾘ ) master (师) is topped with decorations (一) to show his mastery.
Radical 口 (mouth) suggests that questions (吗) is related to speaking (口). 马 (mǎ) hints at the pronunciation of 吗 (ma).
不 as a character has the same meaning as it does as a radical.

A child (子) sits under the roof (龸) of a school building to learn (学). 

(Note that the upper part of 学 is not exactly 龸, but a unique variation of it.)
Ancient Chinese people believed that snakes (也) are greedy: they want this and also (也) that.
人 as a character has the same meaning as it does as a radical.
中 as a character has the same meaning as it does as a radical.
An ancient country is an enclosure (囗) with an imperial jade (玉), which represents the king, at its center.
The horn (羊) of a grown-up (大) goat is traditionally considered a beautiful decoration.

The left part of 那 depicts a thick beard, which was uncommon amongst ancient Chinese men. 

那 originally points to a faraway foreign city (阝) where men grew thick beard. It was later generalized to mean "over there" or "that" (something more distant than "here" or "this").

Due to the extreme abstraction of this character as it evolved, its historic explanation isn't very helpful for remembering it. You can still use your imagination to create your own memory aid though! :)
While 片 as a radical means a sheet of wood, 片 as a character and can refer to any broad flat pieces.
In traditional agricultural societies, fathers (爸) were laboring men (父). 巴 (bā) suggests the pronunciation of 爸 (bà).
Radical 女 indicates that a mother (妈) is a woman (女). 马 (mǎ) hints at the pronunciation of 妈 (mā).

Due to the extreme abstraction of this character as it evolved, its historic explanation isn't very helpful for remembering it. You can still use your imagination to create your own memory aid though! :)
In a schoolhouse (宀), children (子) are learning Chinese characters (字). 子 (zǐ) also hints at the pronunciation of 字 (zì).
Radical 子 (child) provides the meaning for 孩 (child). 亥 (hài) suggests the pronunciation of 孩 (hái).
Birds (隹) chirp to communicate (讠), asking who (谁) is there. 隹 (zhuī) also suggests the pronunciation of 谁 (shuí/shéi).

Radical 也 (snake) represents animals in general here. Animals, as opposed to oneself (me) or another person (you), are always referred to with the third-person pronoun. And because the radical 女 means "woman", 她 is the third person pronoun for women.
In Ancient China, livestocks (豕) under a shelter (宀) is the essence of a home (家).
弟 as a radical means "rank." 弟 as a character means “those who rank lower in the family, i.e. younger brothers."

Radical 也 (snake) represents animals in general here. Animals, as opposed to oneself (me) or another person (you), are always referred to with the third-person pronoun. And because the radical 亻means "man", 他 is the third person pronoun for man.
While 大 as a radical can mean both "adult" and "big", 大 as a character only means "big."

可 means to play instruments or to sing. 哥, which consists of two 可, means that two people are singing or playing instruments to each other --- a practice that was common between two male friends in Ancient China. 哥's meaning was later extended to "young man" and "brothers". 可 (kě) also suggests the pronunciation of 哥 (gē).
While 儿 as a radical is gender-neutral, 儿 as a character sometimes specifically refers to sons.
A piece of meat (⺝) in your hand (𠂇) is yours; you own (有) it.

Here 几 represents a current. A person who is drowning (没 mò) in a current (几) of water (氵) flails his hands (又). A drowned person is gone, so 没 is later generalized to mean the absence of something (when pronounced as "méi").
While 高 as a radical depicts a tall building, Chinese does not distinguish between "tall" and "high": both meaning are expressed by the character 高.
In Ancient China, a traditional agricultural society, the men (男) use their strength (力) to work in the field (田).
Here, 几 visually represents a small stool. There are usually a few (1st definition) small stools around the table. But how many (2nd definition) exactly?
While 口 as a radical only means mouth, 口 as a character is generalized to also mean many other types of opening.
两 as a character has the same meaning as it does as a radical.

和 originally refers to the harmonious music produced by blowing (口) a primitive wind instrument: the hollow grain stalk (禾). On an abstract level, 和 also means "and" because "A and B" indicates a harmonious, compatible relationship (in contrast with "A but B", "A or B"). 禾 (hé) also provides the pronunciation of 和 (hé).
二 as a character has the same meaning as it does as a radical.
In the past (古), individual craftsmen (亻) made (做) weapons (攵) by hand.
People use tools (工 as a radical) to do work (工 as a character).
Radical 亻(person) indicates that work (作) is created by people (as opposed to nature). 乍 (zuo) provides the pronunciation for 作.

A city (阝) populated by a lot of people (者) is called a metropolis (都 dū). The radical 者 (zhū) also suggests the pronunciation of 都 (dū). 

Metropolises have all the things people want to buy, so 都 is later generalized to mean "all" (when pronounced as "dōu").

Due to the extreme abstraction of this character as it evolved, its historic explanation isn't very helpful for remembering it. You can still use your imagination to create your own memory aid though!
In addition to the meaning "moon," 月 as a character also means "month" because a month is one period of the moon's rotation.

Due to the extreme abstraction of this character as it evolved, its historic explanation isn't very helpful for remembering it. You can still use your imagination to create your own memory aid though!
丂 here represents breath. When counting (号) out loud, one exhales (丂) from one's mouth (口).
Sky (天) is the space (一) above a person (大). 天 also means "day" because a day is the period for the sun to complete a full cycle of 's rise and fall in the sky.
In addition to the meaning "sun," 日 as a character also means "day" because a day is the period for the sun to complete a full cycle of 's rise and fall in the sky.
年 as a character has the same meaning as it does as a radical.
Two dusks (夕) per day would be too much (多).
As there are no useful mnemonic explanations, we suggest you focus on practicing the stroke order to help you remember this character.
In Chinese folklore, a monster called 岁 comes out of the mountain (山) at dusk (夕) every New Year. The monster's name 岁 then came to represent each year (岁).
One uses one's mouth (口) to beg (乞) for something to eat (吃).
Radical 饣 (food) indicates 饭 is related to food. Radical 反 (fǎn) hints at the pronunciation of 饭 (fàn).

Radical 心 indicates that 怎 is related to a feeling. As for its exact meaning, due to the exreme abstraction of this character as it evolved, its historic explanation isn't very helpful for remembering it. You can still use your imagination to create your own memory aid though!

A wooden (木) goat (羊) has the appearance (样) of sheep but is not a goat. We can group things into types (2nd definition) based on their looks (1st definition). 

样 is similar to the English word "form," which can mean both "shape" and "kind."
The extra dot indicates that 太 is a bit bigger than big (大), so it's very (太) big, or even too (太) big.
To sincerely thank (谢) someone, you should go to them in person (身) and speak (讠) your gratitude even if there is a long distance (寸) between you guys.

The plants (艹) that you pick up (采) to eat are called vegetables (菜). Radical 采 (cǎi) hints at the pronunciation of 菜 (cài).

菜 also means dishes because Chinese dishes contain a lot of vegetables.

When one is told not (不) to walk (辶), he or she will still (还) stand at the same place after some time (1st definition). 还 can also mean many many other things as an adverb, so we suggest that you learn its other definitions in context as you encounter them.

Due to the extreme abstraction of this character as it evolved, its historic explanation isn't very helpful for remembering it. You can still use your imagination to create your own memory aid though!
Radical 亻 indicates 们 is related to people. 门 (mén) provides the pronunciation of 们 (men).

Where fire (灬) has occupied (占), it leaves spots (点) of soot.

X点 means "X o' clock" because an hour is a bit (点) of a day.
半 as a character has the same meaning as it does as a radical.
The sun (日) goes down in the evening (1st definition), which is late (2nd definition) in the day. 免 (miǎn) hints at the vowel and tone of 晚 (wǎn).
While 上 as a radical only means "up," 上 as a character also means "to go up."
见 as a character has the same meaning as it does as a radical.
As there are no useful mnemonic explanations, we suggest you focus on practicing the stroke order to help you remember this character.
Here 一 is indicative of one line, so 一 as a character means one.
三 as a character has the same meaning as it does as a radical.
四 as a character has the same meaning as it does as a radical.
五 as a character has the same meaning as it does as a radical.
As there are no useful mnemonic explanations, we suggest you focus on practicing the stroke order to help you remember this character.
七 as a character has the same meaning as it does as a radical.

Due to the extreme abstraction of this character as it evolved, its historic explanation isn't very helpful for remembering it. You can still use your imagination to create your own memory aid though!

白 (bái) provides the pronunciation for 百 (bǎi). Due to the extreme abstraction of this character as it evolved, its historic explanation isn't very helpful for remembering its meaning. You can still use your imagination to create your own memory aid though!
北 as a character has the same meaning as it does as a radical.
文 as a character has the same meaning as it does as a radical.

这 originally meant to greet people properly, i.e. in a cultured (文) way, when they come (辶) to you. Later, it was generalized to refer to a person or thing that is close to you, i.e. "this" and "here."
To protect someone you love (爱) (e.g. your friends 友), you take (爫) them into a shelter (冖).
白 as a character has the same meaning as it does as a radical.
京 as a character has the same meaning as it does as a radical.

The sun (日) provides light during the day, and fire (灬) provides light during the night, so 照 originally means "radiate or light up" and "light ray."

照 was later extended to mean "mirror" because mirrors reflect light. 召 (zhào) provides the pronounciation.
When you are happy (欢), you clap your hands (又) and laugh so hard that you are bent over (欠).
女 means “female”. One's younger sister (妹) must be a female (女). 未 (wèi) suggests the sound "ei" in the pronunciation of 妹 (mèi).
fields.example_1_character: younger sister + younger sister (repeated to show affection)

fields.mnemonic_explanation: 匚 represents a heart torn open from the right by an arrow (矢). A man shot by arrow needs medical (医) support.

Radical 日 (sun) suggests that stars (星) are similar to the sun (日) in that they are bright objects in the sky. The difference is that stars were also used by Ancient Chinese people to prophecy their lives (生).

Ancient Chinese people used the waxing and waning of the moon (月) to track time (i.e. month), so radical 月 (moon) indicates that 期 is related to time. 

期 also means "to expect" (something in future time). 

Radical 其 (qí) suggests the pronunciation of 期 (qī).

Ancient Chinese used writing brushes (聿) to write down the rules (律). 
聿 (yù) suggests the pronounciation of 律 (lǜ).

fields.definition_1: to make an appointment, to invite
fields.mnemonic_explanation: Due to the extreme abstraction of this character as it evolved, its historic explanation isn't very helpful for remembering it. You can still use your imagination to create your own memory aid though!
While 子 as a radical only means child, 子 as a character means both child (1st definition) and small (2nd definition).

1st definition: Something in the middle (央) of a flat grassland would stand out and therefore be "outstanding". 央 (yāng) also suggests the pronunciation of 英 (yīng).

2nd definition: 英 (yīng) is a phonetic translation of the "ing" sound in "England."
壴 means "drum". 口 depicts an open mouth, which can be seen as a laugh. Ancient Chinese played drums (壴) and laughed (口) when there were events worth celebrating and when they were happy (喜).

Radical 刂 indicates that carving (刻 2nd definition) uses a knife (刂). The Ancient Chinese also carved (刻 2nd definition) sections into stone tablets to make clocks. 刻 was then generalized to mean a unit of time, more specifically a quarter of an hour  (刻 1st definition).
fields.example_1_character: time + a quarter of an hour

fields.definition_2: indicates the completion of an action
fields.mnemonic_explanation: 了 primarily conveys a sense of past tense or perfect tense (completion of an action), but it has many subtleties and other meanings, so we suggest that you learn its specific definitions in context as you encounter them.

In ancient China, cloth strips (纟) were used to tie (1st definition) many things together, including robes. Later, buttons were invented to replace robe belts, so 纽 also came to mean buttons (2nd definiiton).
